The IM-1 mission's capture of the Moon represents a milestone in private lunar exploration efforts. The precision of its trajectory corrections highlights the technological prowess and dedication of the team behind this ambitious endeavor.

science.author: Web Desk
science.title: AstroSat observatory unravels mysteries of black hole X-Ray binary system
science.description: India's pioneering space astronomy observatory, AstroSat, has facilitated an international team of scientists in uncovering the enigmatic nature of the X-ray binary system known as MAXI J1820+070
science.content: India's pioneering space astronomy observatory, AstroSat, has facilitated an international team of scientists in uncovering the enigmatic nature of the X-ray binary system known as MAXI J1820+070, home to a black hole, announced ISRO. X-ray binaries, named for their emission of X-rays, comprise a normal star and a collapsed star, which may manifest as a white dwarf, neutron star, or a black hole, as per NASA. MAXI J1820+070 is identified as a low-mass X-ray binary housing a black hole as a compact entity. The study, titled A Multi-Wavelength Spectral Study of MAXI J1820+070 in the Soft and Hard States, conducted by an international team, provides distinctive insights into the behavior of this transient black hole X-ray binary during its 2018 outburst,said a statrement from the ISRO.The team, spearheaded by researchers from the Inter-University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics, Pune, incorporates scientists from India, the United Kingdom, Abu Dhabi, and Poland. This comprehensive analysis has been accepted for publication in The Astrophysical Journal. Positioned at a distance of 9,800 light-years from Earth, MAXI J1820+070 was initially detected during its outburst in 2018 utilizing the MAXI instrument aboard the International Space Station (ISS), ISRO revealed. Owing to its proximity to Earth and its remarkable luminosity upon discovery, emerging as the second brightest object in the X-ray sky, MAXI J1820+070 garnered substantial attention within the astronomy community, prompting numerous observation campaigns across various electromagnetic bands, elucidated the agency.

comments.comment: AstroSat's contributions to unraveling the mysteries of the black hole X-ray binary system highlight the significance of India's space astronomy capabilities. The findings of this study enhance our understanding of the dynamics of black hole environments and binary star systems.

The insights provided by AstroSat into the X-ray binary system MAXI J1820+070 offer valuable information about the behavior of black holes and their companion stars. This research enhances our understanding of the processes governing these exotic celestial objects.

science.author: Jess Battison
science.title: Astronaut captures once in a lifetime shot of Earth on his last full day in space
science.description: The NASA astronaut's photos from the International Space Station look like something out of a sci-fi movie
science.content: The idea of being up in space seems pretty cool in itself, getting to look out into, well, space or over Earth from above. Actually, I guess that could seem pretty scary.For one astronaut, however, what made his experience even cooler is the once in a lifetime photo he managed to take.NASA astronaut Terry W. Virts had been trying to capture one particular view for his six month mission when he was living and working on the International Space Station.

comments.comment: The breathtaking photos captured by the astronaut offer a unique perspective of Earth's landscapes from the International Space Station. These images inspire awe and appreciation for the beauty and fragility of our planet.

The astronaut's photographs provide a captivating glimpse of Earth's natural wonders and human civilization from the vantage point of space. Such imagery fosters a deeper connection to our planet and underscores the importance of preserving its environment.

science.author: Ben Turner
science.title: NASA grabbed a whopping 120 grams of rubble from asteroid Bennu, and it may contain the seeds of life
science.description: NASA's final tally shows that OSIRIS-REx collected roughly 4 ounces (120 grams) of material from asteroid Bennu. The sample collected from the "potentially hazardous" asteroid is thought to contain some of the earliest precursors for life.
science.content: NASA scientists have finally tallied how much material a spacecraftsnatched from a distant "potentially hazardous" asteroid, and it turns out they've got more than double what they expected.The sample — roughly 4.3 ounces (122 grams) of rocky space rubble that the OSIRIS-REx spacecraft collected from the asteroid Bennu — could contain some of the earliest precursors for life and is the first space rock ever retrieved by a NASA mission.After landing in the Utah desert on Sept. 24, 2023, the OSIRIS-REx capsule was taken to NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston, where scientists began working to disassemble it — which proved trickier than many anticipated. Two of the capsule's 35 fasteners got stuck, forcing  NASA researchers to initially only collect about 2.48 ounces (70.3 grams) of sample resting on the lid of the canister.Then, after specially designing and testing bespoke tools for the task, scientists finally opened the lid's last two clasps. After fully disassembling it, they retrieved 1.81 ounces (51.2 grams) more of the asteroid from inside.

comments.comment: The significant amount of rubble collected from asteroid Bennu offers a unique opportunity to study the composition and history of these primitive space rocks. Analyzing these samples could unlock valuable insights into the early stages of solar system formation and the potential for extraterrestrial life.

The successful collection of material from asteroid Bennu by OSIRIS-REx represents a remarkable achievement in space exploration. These samples hold immense scientific value and may hold clues to the origins of life on Earth and beyond.

science.title: NASA-Funded Science Projects Tuning In to 'Eclipse Radio'
science.description: On April 8, 2024, a total solar eclipse will cross parts of the United States. For millions of people along the path of totality, where the Moon will completely cover the Sun, it may feel like an eerie daytime darkness has descended as temperatures drop and w…
science.content: On April 8, 2024, a total solar eclipse will cross parts of the United States. For millions of people along the path of totality, where the Moon will completely cover the Sun, it may feel like an eerie daytime darkness has descended as temperatures drop and wind patterns change. But these changes are mild compared to what happens some 100 to 400 miles above our heads in an electrically conductive layer of our atmosphere known as the ionosphere, where the “false night” of an eclipse is amplified a hundredfold. Three NASA-funded experiments will investigate the eclipse’s effects on the ionosphere through the power of radio, a technology well suited to studying this enigmatic layer of our atmosphere. Whether you’ve heard of the ionosphere or not, you’ve likely taken advantage of its existence. This electric blanket of particles is critical for long-distance AM and shortwave radio. Radio operators aim their transmitters into the sky, “bouncing” signals off this layer and around the curvature of Earth to extend their broadcast by hundreds or even thousands of miles.

comments.comment: NASA's funding of science projects aimed at studying the effects of the upcoming total solar eclipse demonstrates the agency's commitment to advancing our understanding of celestial phenomena. These initiatives harness the collective efforts of scientists and citizens alike, fostering collaboration and engagement in space science.

The 'Eclipse Radio' projects funded by NASA offer a unique opportunity to study the dynamic changes in Earth's ionosphere during a total solar eclipse. By leveraging radio technology and citizen science, these initiatives enable widespread participation and contribute to our knowledge of space weather and its impact on our planet.

science.author: PTI
science.title: ISRO’s unique & inexpensive space platform POEM-3 achieves all payload objectives
science.description: ISRO said POEM-3 flew with nine payloads from Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre, Physical Research Laboratory, academia, and space start-ups.
science.content: After achieving the objectives of all experiments onboard, the PSLV Orbital Experimental Module based on the last stage of the PSLV rocket that carried XPoSat to space on New Year’s day is likely to enter the Earth’s atmosphere and burn up within the next 75 days. This will ensure that the mission leaves no debris, Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) said.The agency on Saturday also announced that its meteorological satellite INSAT-3DS has been sent off to Sriharikota from U R Rao Satellite Centre, Bengaluru, where it was developed. The mission is likely to be launched mid-February onboard GSLV.To cut down on space debris, ISRO has been taking steps such as lowering the orbit of defunct satellites and last stages of the rockets, and removing excess fuel since last year.In fact, the orbit of POEM-3 (PSLV Orbital Experimental Module-3) was lowered from 650 km to 350 km after the space observatory XPoSat was placed in orbit to reduce the time the platform remains in orbit.The space agency said that the platform had completed 400 orbits by the 25th day. During this period, each of the nine experiments were put to operation and their performance determined. The experiments include the Women Engineered Satellite (WESAT) developed by LBS Institute of Technology for Women to study the comparison between solar irradiance and UV index, a radiation shielding experiment, an amateur radio, three propulsion systems by space start-ups, and an interplanetary dust count experiment by Physical Research Laboratory. Two types of fuel cell systems developed by the Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre were also onboard.

comments.comment: The successful completion of all payload objectives by ISRO's POEM-3 platform demonstrates India's prowess in developing innovative and cost-effective space technologies. This achievement highlights the country's growing capabilities in space research and exploration.

ISRO's POEM-3 platform exemplifies the agency's commitment to advancing space exploration through affordable and versatile solutions. This accomplishment paves the way for future missions and collaborations, further solidifying India's position as a key player in the global space community.

science.author: Anonna Dutt
science.title: ISRO’s ‘naughty boy’ rocket to launch India’s latest weather satellite today
science.description: GSLV-F14 to lift off at 5.35 pm; INSAT-3DS to have a mission life of 10 years
science.content: Meteorological satellite INSAT-3DS will be launched into space onboard a Geosynchronous Launch Vehicle (GSLV) Saturday evening, in a crucial mission for the rocket nicknamed naughty boy for its spott… The GSLV-F14 will lift off at 5.35 pm Saturday from the Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota, the ISRO said. It will be the rocket’s 16th mission overall and its 10th flight using the indigenously developed cryogenic engine.The mission’s success will be crucial for the GSLV, which is scheduled to carry later this year the Earth observation satellite, NISAR, which is being jointly developed by NASA and ISRO.NISAR will map the entire globe in 12 days and provide “spatially and temporally consistent” data for understanding changes in Earth’s ecosystems, ice mass, sea level rise and natural hazards such as earthquakes and tsunamis, according to ISRO.

comments.comment: The launch of India's latest weather satellite onboard GSLV-F14 underscores ISRO's ongoing efforts to enhance the country's capabilities in space-based weather monitoring and forecasting. This mission marks another milestone in India's space program and contributes to the nation's scientific and technological advancement.

The deployment of INSAT-3DS by ISRO's GSLV-F14 rocket represents a significant advancement in India's meteorological capabilities. This satellite will play a crucial role in monitoring weather patterns and enhancing disaster preparedness, benefiting millions of people across the country.

science.author: Paul Hill
science.title: UK Space Agency to spend £7.4 million on Moon, Mars and Venus projects
science.description: The UK Space Agency has announced £7.4 million in funding for several global space projects. This funding will help the UK play a part in upcoming space exploration while keeping costs quite low. Read more...
science.content: The UK Space Agency (UKSA) has announced £7.4 million in funding for several projects that will ensure the country plays a part in global space missions to the Moon, Mars, and Venus in the coming years. The funding will allow various UK institutions to work with the likes of ISRO (Indian space agency) and NASA (American space agency).One of the seven projects that was granted funding will involve the Space Science and Exploration Bilateral Programme helping Royal Holloway, University of London, develop software for ISRO’s Chandrayaan-2 and Shukrayaan orbiters. The Chandrayaan-2 orbiter will help detect sub-surface ice on the lunar south pole while Shukrayaan will map the surface of Venus – this work will be important because Venus is covered in thick cloud making it difficult to map the surface.The project getting the most funding is called I-MIM (International Mars Ice Mapper) and will involve The Open University working with the Canadian Space Agency (CSA). The Open University will work on high performance detectors for the Mars multispectral and stereo imager for the International Mars Ice Mapper mission so that a map can be made of accessible water ice deposits on the Martian surface.

comments.comment: The UK Space Agency's investment in Moon, Mars, and Venus projects reflects the nation's commitment to advancing space exploration and scientific research. This funding will facilitate collaborative efforts with international partners and contribute to groundbreaking discoveries in planetary science.

The allocation of £7.4 million by the UK Space Agency for Moon, Mars, and Venus projects underscores the country's ambition to play a significant role in future space exploration endeavors. These initiatives demonstrate the UK's commitment to scientific discovery and technological innovation on a global scale.

science.author: Paul Hill
science.title: SpaceX to launch Odysseus Moon lander for Intuitive Machines
science.description: This Week in Rocket Launches we have a fair few missions coming up. Japan will be doing the second test flight of its H3 rocket while SpaceX will be launching another company's lunar lander. Read more...
science.content: This Week in Rocket Launches we have a fair few missions coming up. The most interesting launch will be a Falcon 9 on Wednesday which will be carrying a Nova-C lander called Odysseus for the company Intuitive Machines. The lander will be aiming to land on the Moon with scientific payloads as part of a NASA programme.SpaceX will be using a Falcon 9 to launch a Nova-C lander called Odysseus for Intuitive Machines. This mission is called IM-1 and will be heading to the Moon as part of NASA’s CLPS (Commercial Lunar Payload Services) programme. Odysseus will try to land on the Moon carrying several bits of equipment for various scientific experiments - it has a surface mission of just 14 days. To learn more, head over to NASA’s dedicated IM-1 page.

comments.comment: SpaceX's upcoming launch of Intuitive Machines' Odysseus Moon lander represents another significant step forward in commercial lunar exploration. This mission highlights the growing partnership between private companies and NASA, advancing humanity's return to the Moon and paving the way for future crewed missions.

The deployment of Intuitive Machines' Odysseus lander by SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket marks a pivotal moment in the commercialization of lunar exploration. This mission demonstrates the increasing role of private companies in space exploration and lays the groundwork for sustained human presence on the Moon.

science.author: Jess Weatherbed
science.title: SpaceX successfully launches Odysseus in bid to return US to the lunar surface
science.description: The Nova-C “Odysseus” lander built by Intuitive Machines was successfully launched by SpaceX on Thursday, aiming to be the first US spacecraft to touch down on the Moon in 50 years.
science.content:
Following its successful deployment, the Nova-C spacecraft now faces a two-week journey to reach the Moon’s south pole. | Photo by GREGG NEWTON/AFP via Getty Images

 

 A robotic lunar lander built…A robotic lunar lander built by private aerospace company Intuitive Machines was successfully launched by SpaceX on Thursday, with hopes of being the first American spacecraft to successfully touch down on the Moon’s surface since the 1972 Apollo 17 mission. The Nova-C lander named “Odysseus” was carried into orbit by a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, which launched from Cape Canaveral at 1:05AM ET on February 15th.The launch was originally scheduled to take place on Wednesday but was delayed due to concerns regarding the temperature of the rocket’s methane fuel. Shortly after liftoff, SpaceX confirmed that the IM-1 mission’s Odysseus lander had been successfully deployed and that the first stage of the Falcon 9 rocket that delivered it into space had also landed back at Cape Canaveral. Odysseus is now making its way to the Moon’s south pole — a region of particular scientific interest due to the occurrence of water ice — where it’s expected to touch down on February 22nd.

comments.comment: SpaceX's launch of the Nova-C "Odysseus" lander for Intuitive Machines marks a significant milestone in the revitalization of American lunar exploration. This mission represents the first step in NASA's Artemis program and sets the stage for renewed human missions to the Moon.

The successful deployment of the Nova-C spacecraft by SpaceX signifies a resurgence in American leadership in lunar exploration. Intuitive Machines' Odysseus lander embodies the spirit of innovation and collaboration, paving the way for sustained human presence on the Moon and beyond.

science.author: Simon Sharwood
science.title: Japan's space program seeks reboot with Wednesday launch
science.description:
Second test flight for failed H3 booster after a run of bad luck
Japan will on Wednesday try to reboot its space program with a second test flight for its H3 booster.…
science.content:
Japan will on Wednesday try to reboot its space program with a second test flight for its H3 booster.
The H3 has been a decade in the making and can launch under its own power, or with theassistance of two or four external boosters. The craft's payload capabilities don't vastly exceed the workhorse H-IIA that Japan has successfully launched almost 50 times, but it is cheaper to operate. Japan's space exploration agency (JAXA) hopes the H3 will therefore allow it to launch more of its own payloads and win business. The launcher will also help JAXA's contributions to the International Space Station.Sadly, March 2023's debut H3 launch did not go well. At the time, JAXA thought the command to ignite its second stage was not received. After observing telemetry suggesting the rocket had worryingly slowed its ascent, JAXA sent an instruction to self-destruct. That message was received and executed, sending the H3 and the land observation satellite it carried to their doom.

comments.comment: Japan's efforts to reboot its space program with the second test flight of the H3 booster demonstrate the nation's resilience and determination in the face of setbacks. This launch represents a crucial step forward in Japan's pursuit of space exploration and scientific discovery.

The upcoming test flight of Japan's H3 booster represents a significant milestone in the nation's space program. This launch underscores Japan's commitment to advancing space exploration and technology, laying the groundwork for future missions and international collaborations.

science.title: Global Implications: More Aerosol Particles Than Thought Are Forming Over Siberia
science.description: Recent research has discovered that, in contrast to earlier assumptions, substantial quantities of aerosol particles are generated across extensive regions of the West Siberian taiga during spring. These findings indicate that rising temperatures can greatly …
science.content: University of Helsinki researchers discovered extensive aerosol particle formation in the West Siberian taiga, contradicting previous beliefs and linking it to heatwave conditions and a warming climate. This significant finding, enhancing understanding of climate interactions, calls for more research in boreal forests to inform climate modeling and policy decisions. Credit: SciTechDaily.comRecent research has discovered that, in contrast to earlier assumptions, substantial quantities of aerosol particles are generated across extensive regions of the West Siberian taiga during spring. These findings indicate that rising temperatures can greatly influence the climate due to this phenomenon.Aerosol particles significantly contribute to the Earth’s cooling process. They can impact the amount of sunlight that reaches the Earth’s surface either directly or indirectly by aiding in cloud formation. These particles originate from various gas molecules and are found all over the planet.To understand the circumstances in which these particles are formed, researchers conduct measurements in various environments all over the world. For example, the Finnish flagship station SMEAR II has conducted measurements in the boreal forest for 25 years.However, the boreal forest is an extremely large area, and much of its contribution to aerosol formation has still not been explored, especially in its Siberian and Canadian parts.Previous studies have suggested that particle formation is rare in Siberia. However, a recent study by the University of Helsinki showed that particle formation in Siberia was frequent and was connected to heat conditions. The results of the study were published in the journal Environmental Research Letters.

comments.comment: The discovery of increased aerosol particle formation over Siberia underscores the complex interactions between climate change and atmospheric processes. Understanding these phenomena is crucial for predicting and mitigating the impacts of environmental change.

The research revealing elevated aerosol particle levels in Siberia highlights the urgent need for comprehensive strategies to address the drivers of air pollution and climate change. Efforts to mitigate these impacts are essential for safeguarding global environmental and human health.

science.author: Ben Turner
science.title: James Webb telescope finds ancient galaxy larger than our Milky Way, and it's threatening to upend cosmology
science.description: Astronomers believe the first galaxies formed around giant halos of dark matter. But a newly discovered galaxy dating to roughly 13 billion years ago mysteriously appeared long before that process should have occurred.
science.content:
The James Webb Space Telescope
 (JWST) has found a galaxy in the early universe that's so massive, it shouldn't exist, posing a "significant challenge" to the standard model of cosmology, The galaxy, called ZF-UDS-7329, contains more stars than the Milky Way, despite having formed only 800 million years into the universe's 13.8 billion-year life span. This means they were somehow born without dark matter seeding their formation, contrary to what the standard model of galaxy formation suggests.How this could have happened is unclear, but much like previous JWST discoveries of other inexplicably massive galaxies in the early universe, it threatens to upend our understanding of how the first matter in the universe formed, or possibly even the standard model of cosmology itself. The researchers published their findings Feb. 14 in the journal Nature.Light travels at a fixed speed through the vacuum of space, so the deeper we look into the universe, the more remote light we intercept and the further back in time we see. This is what enabled the researchers to use JWST to spot ZF-UDS-7329 roughly 11.5 billion years in the past.By studying the spectra of light coming from the stars of this extremely distant galaxy, the researchers found that the stars were born 1.5 billion years prior to that observation, or roughly 13 billion years ago.

comments.comment: The discovery of an ancient galaxy larger than our Milky Way challenges current cosmological models and opens new avenues for understanding the formation and evolution of galaxies in the early universe. Such findings highlight the ongoing quest to unravel the mysteries of cosmic evolution.

The identification of a massive ancient galaxy by the James Webb Space Telescope underscores the need for continued exploration and observation of the cosmos. These discoveries push the boundaries of our understanding and inspire awe at the vastness and complexity of the universe.

science.title: Breaking the Rules – Important Molecular Pathway for Control of Aging Discovered
science.description: Research on the roundworm species C. elegans has demonstrated that disruptions in the transfer of RNA between cells across various tissues can lead to a shortened lifespan. Cells in various tissues interact by sharing RNA molecules. A study conducted by scien…
science.content: New research found that imbalances in RNA communication, both within and from outside the organism, can shorten the lifespan of Caenorhabditis elegans, offering new insights into the aging process Cells in various tissues interact by sharing RNA molecules. A study conducted by scientists from the State University of Campinas (UNICAMP) in Brazil, using the roundworm species Caenorhabditis elegans, discovered that disruptions in this method of communication can lead to a reduced lifespan for the organism. The study was recently published in the journal Gene. The findings contribute to a better understanding of the aging process and associated diseases.Previous research showed that some types of RNA can be transferred from one cell to another, mediating intertissue communication, of the kind that occurs with proteins and metabolites, for example. This is considered a mechanism for signaling between organs or neighboring cells. It’s part [of the physiopathology] of several diseases and of the organism’s normal functioning said Marcelo Mori, corresponding author of the article and a professor at the Institute of Biology (IB-UNICAMP)The study was conducted at UNICAMP’s Obesity and Comorbidities Research Center (OCRC), one of the Research, Innovation, and Dissemination Centers (RIDCs) funded by FAPESP. It was also funded via a project for which Mori is the principal investigator.

comments.comment: The discovery of a key molecular pathway for controlling aging in C. elegans sheds light on fundamental mechanisms underlying the aging process. Understanding these pathways could lead to the development of interventions to promote healthy aging in humans.

The identification of RNA communication disruptions contributing to shortened lifespan in C. elegans offers valuable insights into the genetic basis of aging. This research paves the way for targeted interventions to modulate aging-related pathways and potentially extend healthy lifespan.

science.author: Nicholas R. Longrich
science.title: 'Cut down in their prime': Dinosaurs were thriving in Africa before the asteroid hit
science.description: The discovery of predatory dinosaurs in marine sediments in Morocco suggests life was abundant and diversifying at the end of the Cretaceous period.
science.content: 66 million years ago, the last dinosaurs vanished from Earth. We're still trying to understand why. New fossils of abelisaurs —  distant relatives of the tyrannosaurs —  from north Africa suggest tha… Paleontologist, evolutionary biologist and sometimes archaeologist from Kodiak, Alaska. I'm currently based at the University of Bath. Interested in how the world came to be and why it's the way it is, as opposed to some other way.I study dinosaurs, among other things - pterosaurs, fossil birds, lizards and snakes. I'm especially interested in understanding macroevolution: large-scale evolutionary patterns and processes. The evolution of organisms and ecosystems over millions and billions of years, the evolution of complex adaptations like bird flight, the snake body plan, and the human mind.I'm interested in the idea that macroevolution is more than just lots of microevolution. Over long periods of time, at large scales, and in the evolution of complex structures, different dynamics come into play; that over time, the processes of evolution itself have evolved. Recently, I've become interested in the evolution of the human species

comments.comment: The discovery of thriving dinosaur populations in Africa before the asteroid impact provides valuable insights into the diversity and distribution of prehistoric ecosystems. Studying these ancient habitats enhances our understanding of the ecological dynamics leading up to the mass extinction event.

The fossil evidence of abundant predatory dinosaurs in Africa prior to the mass extinction event sheds light on the resilience and adaptability of dinosaur communities. Understanding the ecological context of these findings deepens our knowledge of the factors influencing dinosaur survival and extinction.

science.author: Dr. Alfredo Carpineti
science.title: Smallest Star Ever Discovered And It's Only A Tiny Bit Bigger Than Earth
science.description: And it orbits its companion with the shortest period ever!
science.content: Astronomers have reported an incredible stellar discovery. Actually, they've reported two incredible discoveries: they have found the smallest star ever and it orbits its companion with the smallest known period for binary stars at just 20.5 minutes.The star is part of a binary system that has been called TMTS J0526 and is located 2,760 light-years from Earth. J0526B is a hot subdwarf star and we are not exaggerating when we say it is tiny. It has a radius just seven times that of Earth. To compare, Jupiter’s radius is 11.2 times Earth’s own, Saturn's is 9.5, and Neptune's is four times Earth's. This is the smallest star ever discovered by volume, and yet it is still a star. Packed into that small volume is about one-third of the mass of the Sun so this tiny star weighs about 350 times that of Jupiter. The heavier object, J0526A, is a white dwarf that weighs about 74 percent of the Sun. It is rich in carbon and oxygen, indicating what kind of star it evolved from. White dwarfs are the destiny of stars like the Sun. Not massive enough to go supernova, the small stars evolve into red giants before shedding their outer layers, exposing an extremely dense degenerate core in a volume not much bigger than our planet.

comments.comment: The identification of the smallest known star, orbiting its companion with the shortest period ever observed, expands our understanding of stellar evolution and binary systems. These findings contribute to ongoing research on the diversity and properties of stars across the universe.

The discovery of the smallest star in existence and its unique orbital characteristics provides valuable insights into stellar formation and dynamics. Such discoveries underscore the vast range of stellar phenomena and the importance of continued exploration to unravel the mysteries of the cosmos.

science.title: Mysterious wave leaves scientists puzzled, as giant cosmic serpent slithers into Milky Way
science.description:
A huge, wave-shaped structure, which extended some 9,000 light-years in length and curled around the Milky Way's spiral arm, was first found by scientists a few years ago. 

The wave, called as Radcliffe Wave, was a line of star-forming gas and its discovery …
science.content:
A huge, wave-shaped structure, which extended some 9,000 light-years in length and curled around the Milky Way's spiral arm, was first found by scientists a few years ago. 
The wave, called as Radcliffe Wave, was a line of star-forming gas and its discovery by scientists was remarkable. However, now removing one of the clouds from this mysterious cosmic serpent, scientists have found that it is moving in our galaxy. A team of scientists, headed by astrophysicist Ralf Konietzka of Harvard University, have now discovered that the Radcliffe Wave, just like other objects in the Milky Way, is in motion. Scientists have also discovered that the wave is not moving in an orbital motion around the galactic centre but is oscillating as a periodic travelling wave.Spacecraft Gaia has been collecting information on the three-dimensional properties of the Milky Way, using which the scientists mapped the galaxy and discovered the Radcliffe Wave in 2018. The findings were published by the scientists in 2020 after putting together the structure's 3D map.

comments.comment: The discovery of the Radcliffe Wave, a colossal structure spanning thousands of light-years, poses intriguing questions about the dynamics and formation of the Milky Way galaxy. Further studies are needed to unravel the origins and implications of this enigmatic cosmic feature.

The identification of the Radcliffe Wave challenges our understanding of the Milky Way's structure and evolution, offering new insights into the complex interplay of galactic dynamics and cosmic phenomena. Exploring such enigmatic structures fuels curiosity and drives advancements in astrophysical research.

science.author: Ashley Strickland
science.title: Famous fossil is really just paint, rocks and a couple of bones, researchers say
science.description: What was once thought to be a well-preserved fossil of an ancient reptile has been revealed to be a forgery made using black paint, carved rock and a couple of bones.
science.content: The fossil, initially discovered in the Italian Alps in 1931, has the scientific name Tridentinosaurus antiquus. Scientists thought the dark, deep outline of the lizardlike body encased in rock was skin and soft tissue, and they considered the fossil to be a puzzle piece for understanding early reptile evolution. The fossil appeared in book and article citations over the decades, but no one ever studied it in detail. Housed in the collections at the University of Padua’s Museum of Nature and Humankind in Italy, the relic raised many questions about the exact nature of the creature it was in life when additional, similar specimens couldn’t be found.A new, detailed analysis has revealed that the dark color of the fossil isn’t preserved genetic material — it’s just black paint covering a couple of bones and carved rock. The researchers behind the study reported their findings February 15 in the journal Paleontology.

comments.comment: The revelation of the forgery surrounding the supposed ancient reptile fossil underscores the importance of rigorous scientific scrutiny and authentication procedures in paleontological research. This case serves as a cautionary tale highlighting the need for critical evaluation of fossil specimens to ensure the integrity of scientific knowledge.

The exposure of the fossil forgery emphasizes the significance of transparent and meticulous practices in paleontology. By addressing fraudulent claims and ensuring the accuracy of scientific findings, researchers uphold the integrity and credibility of the field, fostering trust and advancement in paleontological science.

science.author: Sarah Bregel
science.title: See the world's tiniest frogs - and why being so small is so hard
science.description: Brachycephalus pulex might be the title holders for world's smallest vertebrate. But it's not easy being green – or tiny.
science.content: cientists believe they may know what the world's smallest vertebrate is. A tiny, pea-sized Brazilian frog called Brachycephalus pulex (or, Brazilian flea toad, even though it is a frog) has the tiniest measurements, according to new research.Back in 2011, Mirco Solé, a researcher at the State University of Santa Cruz in Brazil, was the first to investigate this species' size compared to that of other similar frogs. The sample wasn't large enough at the time to be conclusive, but the most recent research, in which Solé and his team measured the body lengths of 46 flea toads and confirmed the frogs’ maturity and sex by examining their gonads and checking for the presence of vocal slits in their throats (which only males have), was more expansive. It found that male B. pulex frogs measured in at just over 7mm (.28in). Females were slightly larger at just over 8mm (.31in). The smallest female B. pulex frog measured in just over 6mm (.25in).

comments.comment: The discovery of Brachycephalus pulex, the world's tiniest vertebrate, offers insights into the remarkable diversity and adaptation of life forms. Understanding the ecological and evolutionary challenges faced by these diminutive frogs contributes to our appreciation of the complexity and resilience of natural ecosystems.

The exploration of the world's tiniest frogs highlights the incredible diversity and ecological significance of small organisms. Studying these diminutive vertebrates provides valuable insights into the mechanisms of adaptation and survival in diverse environments, enriching our understanding of biodiversity and ecosystem dynamics.

science.author: Robert Lea
science.title: NASA's twin spacecraft will go to the ends of the Earth to combat climate change
science.description: The two satellites of the PREFIRE mission will launch in Spring 2024 and collect data from Earth's poles.
science.content: The shoebox-sized satellites, or Cubesats, in the Polar Radiant Energy in the Far-InfraRed Experiment (PREFIRE), will blast off during the Spring of 2024. Reaching an altitude of between 292 and 403 miles (470 and 650 kilometers) over Earth, the two spacecraft will sit in near-polar orbits, crisscrossing each other in the atmosphere. For the first time, PREFIRE will measure the full spectrum of heat lost from Earth’s polar regions. These frigid areas of our planet effectively act as Earth's thermostat, regulating the climate by venting excess energy received in the tropics. In a nutshell, PREFIRE will make our climate models more accurate — a very important goal as our planet continues to inorganically warm due to human activities.

comments.comment: NASA's PREFIRE mission represents a crucial effort in understanding and combatting climate change by collecting data from Earth's poles. These twin spacecraft will provide valuable insights into the dynamics of polar regions, facilitating informed decisions to mitigate the impacts of global warming.

The launch of NASA's twin spacecraft for the PREFIRE mission underscores the agency's commitment to addressing the urgent challenges of climate change. By studying Earth's poles, these satellites will enhance our understanding of climate dynamics and support efforts to safeguard our planet for future generations.

science.author: Mahnoor Jehangir
science.title: SpaceX's Historic Lunar Quest & A Leap Towards Memory Improvement: Today's Scientific Milestones
science.description: SpaceX Falcon 9 heads to the moon while scientists discover oxytocin neurons can enhance long-term memory. Explore these groundbreaking achievements.
science.content: In an era where the boundaries of human capability and scientific advancement are constantly being pushed, two groundbreaking events stand as testaments to the relentless pursuit of knowledge and exploration. First, a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket embarks on a historic mission, carrying the Intuitive Machines lunar lander to the moon, aiming to achieve the first U.S. lunar landing in over half a century. This mission not only marks a pivotal moment for the commercial space sector but also reignites dreams of lunar exploration. Concurrently, the scientific community heralds a significant breakthrough in the fight against dementia and Alzheimer's, with research demonstrating the potential of activating oxytocin neurons to enhance long-term memory.A Giant Leap for Commercial Space Exploratio The journey of the SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, laden with hopes and the Intuitive Machines lunar lander, represents more than just another mission; it is a beacon of the burgeoning commercial space industry's capabilities and ambition. The success of this mission will not only etch its name in the annals of space exploration but also significantly bolster confidence in commercial space ventures. As the rocket soars towards the moon, it carries with it the aspirations of countless individuals who dream of unlocking the mysteries of our closest celestial neighbor and beyond.

comments.comment: SpaceX's journey to the Moon aboard the Falcon 9 rocket represents a historic milestone in commercial space exploration. This achievement brings humanity one step closer to establishing a sustained presence beyond Earth and unlocking the vast potential of space for scientific discovery and innovation.

The recent discovery regarding oxytocin neurons and their role in enhancing long-term memory exemplifies the profound impact of scientific research on our understanding of the human brain. This breakthrough holds promising implications for cognitive health and neurodegenerative diseases.

science.author: Dr. Katie Spalding
science.title: Is Math Discovered Or Invented?
science.description: We bet we can change your mind.
science.content: For most of us, our mathematical education involved a lot of names. Theres Pythagorass Theorem; the Riemann Hypothesis; Hilberts Hotel, and so many more concepts and theorems intrinsically linked toIt’s a serious question. We’re so used to math being this indispensable tool, letting us unravel the fundamental laws of the Universe, get rich quick, or simply plan the most efficient party guest list, that we don’t often stop to consider where it comes from.So which is it? Is math invented, with all those theorems and concepts so rigorously proved throughout millennia just a byproduct of human perception; or is it discovered, prompting the notion of some factual, real “six” out there in the cosmos somewhere? If you’ve ever found yourself wondering whether a2 + b2 = c2 is some cosmic and immutable truth, or just something we’ve decided is handy for bridge building, you’re in good company. The question of whether math is discovered or invented goes back a very long time: “since at least Plato’s time (4th century [BCE]),” Alexander Paseau, Professor of Mathematical Philosophy at the University of Oxford, tells IFLScience.

comments.comment: The age-old debate on whether math is discovered or invented continues to captivate minds across disciplines. This thought-provoking article challenges conventional perspectives and invites readers to reconsider their fundamental understanding of mathematics and its profound implications for human knowledge.

The question of whether math is discovered or invented delves into the very nature of human perception and reality itself. By exploring this philosophical inquiry, we are prompted to contemplate the essence of mathematics and its role in shaping our understanding of the universe.

science.title: Discuss the contributions of Satyendra Nath Bose to the field of physics and inspiring the advancement of spirit of scientific inquiry among Indians.

comments.comment: Satyendra Nath Bose's contributions to the field of physics, particularly his collaboration with Albert Einstein in formulating Bose-Einstein statistics, have had a profound impact on our understanding of quantum mechanics. His pioneering work continues to inspire scientific inquiry and innovation, leaving an indelible mark on the history of physics.

Satyendra Nath Bose's legacy extends beyond his scientific achievements to his role in fostering a culture of scientific inquiry and innovation in India. His pioneering contributions to physics, coupled with his dedication to education and research, have inspired generations of Indian scientists to pursue excellence and push the boundaries of human knowledge.

science.author: Liu Jia
science.title: Researchers synthesize two new isotopes, osmium-160 and tungsten-156
science.description: Researchers at the Institute of Modern Physics (IMP) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) and their collaborators have synthesized two new isotopes—osmium-160 and tungsten-156—which sheds new light on nuclear structures and hints that lead-164 could be a …
science.content: Researchers at the Institute of Modern Physics (IMP) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) and their collaborators have synthesized two new isotopesosmium-160 and tungsten-156which sheds new light… In this study, researchers carried out the experiment at the gas-filled recoil separator, Spectrometer for Heavy Atoms and Nuclear Structure (SHANS), at the Heavy Ion Research Facility in Lanzhou (HIRFL), China.Using the fusion evaporation reaction, researchers synthesized osmium-160 and tungsten-156 for the first time. They measured the α-particle energy and the half-life of osmium-160, which is an α-emitting isotope. In addition, they determined that the daughter nucleus, tungsten-156, is a β+ emitter with a half-life of 291 ms.With the newly measured α-decay data, researchers derived α-decay reduced width for osmium-160 and compared it with those of other nuclei with 84 neutrons but fewer protons, and they found a surprising trend: The higher the proton number, the lower the decay rate.

comments.comment: The synthesis of osmium-160 and tungsten-156 represents a significant advancement in nuclear physics research, shedding new light on the structure and behavior of atomic nuclei. This breakthrough opens avenues for exploring the fundamental properties of matter and advancing our understanding of the universe at its most fundamental level.

The recent synthesis of osmium-160 and tungsten-156 by researchers at the Institute of Modern Physics showcases the ongoing efforts to expand the known isotopic landscape and uncover new insights into nuclear structure and stability. This achievement contributes to the broader scientific endeavor to unravel the mysteries of the atomic realm.

science.author: Jeff Foust
science.title: Software problem blamed for Firefly Alpha mishap
science.description: A software glitch prevented the upper stage of Firefly Aerospace’s Alpha rocket from completing a second burn during a December launch.
science.content:
WASHINGTON A software glitch prevented the upper stage of Firefly Aerospaces Alpha rocket from completing a second burn during a December launch, stranding its payload in a low orbit.
In a Feb. 20 In a Feb. 20 statement, Firefly said an error with the guidance, navigation and control (GNC) software for the upper stage of the Alpha on the company’s “Fly the Lightning” mission Dec. 22 kept the upper stage from firing as planned to circularize its orbit. That left the upper stage and its payload, a Lockheed Martin technology demonstration satellite, in an orbit with a low perigee.The investigation, which included the company’s own mishap team as well as an independent review, found that the error in the GNC software algorithm “prevented the system from sending the necessary pulse commands to the Reaction Control System (RCS) thrusters ahead of the stage two engine relight.” Firefly didn’t elaborate on the issue, but the RCS thrusters likely would have been used to ensure the stage was in the proper orientation and to settle its tanks so propellant would flow from them into the engine.

comments.comment: The software issue encountered during the Firefly Alpha launch highlights the critical role of robust software systems in ensuring the success and safety of space missions. Identifying and addressing such technical challenges is essential for advancing the reliability and efficiency of launch vehicles and spacecraft.

The incident involving Firefly Aerospace's Alpha rocket underscores the complexities and risks inherent in space exploration. As the industry continues to push boundaries, lessons learned from such setbacks are invaluable for improving technology and processes, ultimately paving the way for safer and more reliable space missions.

science.title: Space debris: 'Grandfather satellite' due to fall to Earth
science.description: Europe's pioneering ERS-2 Earth observation spacecraft will make an uncontrolled dive to destruction.
science.content:
Artwork: Europe's Earth Remote Sensing satellites weighed about 2.5 tonnes at launch
A pioneering European satellite is due to fall to Earth in the coming hours.
ERS-2 was a cutting-edge observatio… The two-tonne ERS-2 spacecraft burnt up in the atmosphere over the Pacific.So far, there have been no eyewitness accounts of the mission's demise or of any debris reaching Earth's surface.ERS-2 was one of a pair of missions launched by the European Space Agency in the 1990s to study the atmosphere, the land and the oceans in novel ways.The duo monitored floods, measured continental and ocean-surface temperatures, traced the movement of ice fields, and sensed the ground buckle during earthquakes.And ERS-2, specifically, introduced a new ability to assess Earth's protective ozone layer.The satellite's return was expected, although uncontrolled. It had no functioning propulsion system to direct its fiery plunge.Radars tracked its fall. Esa says the end came at 17:17 GMT (18:17 CET) +/- one minute, over the North Pacific Ocean between Alaska and Hawaii, about 2,000km west of California.

comments.comment: The impending re-entry of Europe's ERS-2 satellite serves as a stark reminder of the growing issue of space debris and the need for responsible spacefaring practices. As humanity continues to expand its presence in space, mitigating the risks posed by orbital debris is paramount for ensuring the sustainability of space activities.

The planned deorbiting of Europe's ERS-2 satellite underscores the importance of responsible space debris management to safeguard Earth's orbital environment. Efforts to address the accumulation of space junk are essential for preserving the long-term sustainability of space exploration and satellite operations.

science.author: Keith Cooper
science.title: Scientists say 2 solar system dwarf planets may harbor underground oceans
science.description: The puzzling presence of a certain flavor of methane on Eris and Makemake could be hinting at their warm, watery interiors.
science.content: Space is part of Future US Inc, an international media group and leading digital publisher. Visit our corporate site.Future US, Inc. Full 7th Floor, 130 West 42nd Street,Two dwarf planets within our solar system, named Eris and Makemake, might exhibit enough geothermal activity to maintain oceans of liquid water within, according to modeling that describes new observations made with the James Webb Space Telescope.Found deep in the Kuiper Belt, Eris is the icy world that, when it was discovered in January 2005, threw Pluto's status in the solar system into crisis. Just 44 kilometers (27 miles) smaller than Pluto but 25% more massive thanks to a greater concentration of rock in its core, Eris became the prototype dwarf planet. Pluto was inevitably forced to follow suit. Makemake (pronounced Mah-kay-Mah-kay) was spotted two months after Eris, and at 1430 km (888 miles) across is about 1000 km (about 600 miles) smaller than Eris and Pluto.

comments.comment: The potential existence of underground oceans on solar system dwarf planets Eris and Makemake highlights the diversity and complexity of icy bodies beyond the realm of the gas giants. Discovering such subsurface reservoirs of water could provide valuable insights into the origins and evolution of these distant worlds.

The intriguing findings regarding the possible presence of underground oceans on Eris and Makemake open new avenues for planetary science research and exploration. Unraveling the mysteries of these dwarf planets' internal structures could offer valuable clues about the conditions and processes shaping icy bodies in the outer solar system.

general.title: Israel ponders restricting access to one of Islam's holiest sites for Ramadan
general.description: The proposal comes at a time when the war between Israel and Hamas has put Palestinians and Israelis on edge.
general.content: TEL AVIV, Israel – The Muslim holy month of Ramadan is always a period of heightened tensions around Jerusalem's Al-Aqsa Mosque, as hundreds of thousands of worshipers line up to enter one of Islam's holiest sites to pray.But a proposal for new restrictions on worshipers entering the site — also sacred to Jews as the foundation of their ancient temple — by Israel's far-right national security minister has raised tensions at a time when Israel is waging a war in Gaza that has cost tens of thousands of lives, following an attack by Hamas that was the deadliest since Israel's founding.And Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has not yet dismissed the controversial plan proposed by Itamar Ben-Gvir to limit access to the mosque even more than in previous years.Ben-Gvir, who lives in a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank, said on X, formerly known as Twitter, that Israeli security forces should prevent Palestinian residents from the occupied West Bank from entering the Al-Aqsa Mosque, built on huge stone platform in Jerusalem's Old City and known to Muslims as the

general.title: Letitia James says she's prepared to seize Trump's buildings if he can't pay his $354M civil fraud fine
general.description: The New York attorney general made the remarks in an interview with ABC News.
general.content: Four days after a judge ordered former President Donald Trump to pay $354 million in his civil fraud case, New York Attorney General Letitia James told ABC News that she is prepared to seize the former president's assets if he is unable to find the cash to cover the fine.If he does not have funds to pay off the judgment, then we will seek judgment enforcement mechanisms in court, and we will ask the judge to seize his assets,James said in an interview with ABC News' Aaron Katersky.Trump was fined $354.8 million plus approximately $100 million in pre-judgment interest on Friday after Judge Arthur Engoron determined that he inflated his net worth in order get more favorable loan terms.The former president has denied all wrongdoing and has said he will appeal. the strength of her case on appeal, James reiterated that her office would not hesitate to seize Trump's assets -- mentioning Trump's 40 Wall Street skyscraper by name -- if the former president is unable to find the cash to cover the court-ordered disgorgement.

comments.comment: Seizing assets is a significant move in ensuring accountability, especially for high-profile cases.
It's a stark reminder that no one is above the law, regardless of their status or wealth.

general.title: Alabama frozen embryos ruling: What it means for fertility treatments
general.description: The Alabama Supreme Court has ruled that frozen embryos created during fertility treatments should be considered children under state law. Justices issued the ruling Friday in a pair of wrongful death cases brought by couples who had frozen embryos destroyed …
general.content: MONTGOMERY, Ala. (AP) — The Alabama Supreme Court ruled last week that couples who were trying in vitro fertilization and lost frozen embryos in an accident at a south Alabama storage facility can sue under the state’s wrongful death law.Since then, three providers have paused the often-used fertility treatments while they sort out the legal implications.The ruling is the first of its kind and extends a theory championed by some anti-abortion groups — that embryos and fetuses should be considered children and be afforded legal protections — into a new realm.

comments.comment: This ruling sets a precedent that could have far-reaching implications for reproductive rights and legal definitions.
It's a complex ethical issue that requires careful consideration of the rights of the embryos and the autonomy of individuals.

general.title: WHO reports 79 percent increase in measles cases worldwide
general.description: WHO reports a 79 percent increase in cases in 2022 and the number of deaths increased by 43 percent.
general.content: NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WTVF) — The World Health Organization is warning that measles is spreading quickly around the world.WHO reports a 79 percent increase in cases in 2022 and the number of deaths increased by 43 percent.The agency expects an increase in deaths from measles last year as well, with more than 306,000 cases reported.The disease causes a rash as well as other typical signs of illness such as coughing, sneezing, and a runny nose.Luckily from 2020 to 2022 there have been no cases of measles reported in Tennessee, but just last month a case was confirmed to have traveled through the Northern Kentucky International Airport.An elementary school in Florida is on high alert now as four cases of measles have been confirmed there.The measles were declared eradicated more than 20 years ago in the U.S.Health experts believe declining vaccination rates is jeopardizing herd immunity and causing the spike in cases. Herd immunity requires 98 percent of the population to be vaccinated against the disease.This is concerning because the measles is one of the most quickly and easily transmitted diseases.

comments.comment: This underscores the importance of vaccination campaigns and global health initiatives to prevent outbreaks.
Measles resurgence is alarming, highlighting the need for stronger healthcare infrastructure and awareness.

general.title: Farmers protest LIVE: 12 cops injured in attack by farmers in Jind, says SP
general.description: Farmers' protests LIVE updates: Farmers have resumed their ‘Delhi Chalo’ march amid demand for MSP guarantee.
general.content: The ongoing farmer protests have turned a very violent turn with several scops and protestors injured on Wednesday (21st February). A massive clash broke out on the Punjab-Haryana border today between the protestors and Haryana police, in which the farmers attacked the police force using various improvised weapons. Moreover, as per Haryana police, three police personnel have died at the farmer protest sites.As per Haryana Police, the farmer protestors today mixed chilli with stubble and burnt it, creating their own tear gas smoke. They then attacked the police with sharp weapons, and resorted to heavy stone pelting. 12 policemen were seriously injured in the attack.Jind police said that using the cover of smoke, the protestors took out their swords and attacked the police. Some protestors also used spears and machetes. To control the situation, police used tear gas to disperse the farmers. As per reports, some injured were sent to Rajendra Hospital Patiala.AIG, (Administration) and Spokesperson of the Haryana Police, Manisha Chaudhary stated that the Police personnel were surrounded at the Data Singh-Khanori border by the protesting farmers’ who poured chilli powder mixed in the stubble and set it on fire. They also attacked the policemen using sticks and sharp weapons as well as pelted stones. Around 12 policemen sustained serious injuries in the attack.

comments.comment: This incident reflects the ongoing challenges in addressing farmers' grievances and ensuring peaceful protests.
The struggle for fair compensation and recognition of farmers' rights continues amidst growing tensions.

technology.title: "Frightening": YouTubers Split Over OpenAI's Video Tool Sora - NDTV
technology.description: US firm OpenAI debuted a tool last week that can generate highly realistic snippets of video from just a few lines of text, leading content creators to wonder if they are the latest professionals about to be replaced by algorithms.
technology.content: OpenAI said in its announcement that Sora was not yet available to the public.US firm OpenAI debuted a tool last week that can generate highly realistic snippets of video from just a few lines of text, leading content creators to wonder if they are the latest professionals about to be replaced by algorithms.Reactions to the tool, called Sora, have ranged from head-over-heels enthusiasm to alarm over the future direction of the industry.YouTuber Marques Brownlee called it frightening and threatening to see an AI doing his job.Powered By VDO.AIVideo Player is loading.PauseUnmuteFullscreen On the other hand, Caleb Ward, one half of AI filmmaking duo Curious Refuge, told his YouTube followers he could not wait to get his hands on the tool.Yet both Ward and Brownlee agreed that it was a massive moment for their industry.I can't stress enough how big a deal this is for the filmmaking and creative world, said Ward, who recently went viral with a trailer he created for a Wes Anderson-style Star Wars movie.OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT, said in its announcement that Sora was not yet available to the public.The announcement did not specify use cases but said a number of visual artists, designers and filmmakers had been chosen to help test it.

comments.comment: The potential impact of AI on content creation is both fascinating and concerning.
As a content creator, I'm intrigued by the capabilities of Sora but also worried about job security in the face of advancing AI technology.

politics.title: No diversion of temple funds, let BJP leaders read law first: Ramalinga Reddy, Karnataka Minister for Transport & Muzrai
politics.description: The government would use the money from the common pool fund only for the religious purposes of Hindu religious institutions ever since the law came into force in 2003. There has been no instance of its use for any other purpose or for members of other religions or institutions.
politics.content: The government would use the money from the common pool fund only for the religious purposes of Hindu religious institutions ever since the law came into force in 2003. There has been no instance of its use for any other purpose or for members of other religions or institutions.The law, Karnataka Hindu Religious Institutions and Charitable Endowments Act, 1997, in fact, has been around since May 2003. Section 17 of this law provides for setting up of a Common Pool of Funds. In 2011, the BJP government amended the law, enabling the government to collect funds from high income group (A category) temples to support temples with poor incomes (C category) using the common pool fund.A ..Read more at:https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/no-diversion-of-temple-funds-let-bjp-leaders-read-law-first-ramalinga-reddy-karnataka-minister-for-transport-muzrai/articleshow/107917058.cms?utm_source=contentofinterest&utm_medium=text&utm_campaign=cppst
politics.author: Economic Times

comments.comment: This seems to be a sensitive issue in Karnataka politics.
Transparency in fund usage is crucial, especially in matters related to religion and public trust.

politics.title: Russia denies US access to American-Russian former ballerina accused of treason
politics.description: The California resident's U.S.-Russian dual citizenship complicates her case.
politics.content: The California resident's U.S.-Russian dual citizenship complicates her case. Ksenia Karelina, a 33-year-old former ballerina who holds both U.S. and Russian citizenship, was arrested Jan. 27 in the city of Yekaterinburg in central Russia and then jailed in early February for allegedly organizing fundraisers for Ukraine's military, attending pro-Ukraine rallies, and posting messages against Russia's war in Ukraine, according to Russian state media.But even though a longstanding agreement between the U.S. and Russia requires both countries to immediately notify the other if one of their nationals is detained, officials in Washington had virtually no information about her case when she was publicly identified by the FSB -- Russia's Federal Security Service -- earlier this week.
politics.author: ABC News

comments.comment: Tensions between Russia and the US continue.
Dual citizenship adds complexity to legal matters.

politics.title: Congress accuses Modi govt of capturing democracy through extortion
politics.description: "An autocratic Modi Government is capturing democracy through extortion and financial terrorism," Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge said.
